column3: Lucius Vettius Secundus, son of Marcus

column13: Unsure if Augusta Praetoria (Italia) or Augusta Troas (Asia Minor). Tončinić 2011, 204-205; Fadić 1995 168: Troas may be more likely, as Sergia is a common tribe for Asia Minor citizens, and another Member (Gaius Curiatius) does list Augusta Troas as his place of origin (MonumentID 32, CIL 3, 2019).
Domicile is lost as inscription is fragmentary

column3: Lucius Domitius Aquila, son of Lucius
Gaius Domitius Aquilinus, son of Lucius
column13: Stela does not explicitly mention that Gaius from Mylia, but his father/brother commemorated on the same monument is from Mylias

column3: Titus Elvius Salinator, son of Titus
column13: Titus' father, Titus, is recorded to have been part of the Scaptia tribe, so Titus Elvius was likley also a member of the same tribe

It is not certain that Lucius was a member of Legio VII, for the inscription does not explicitly mention service, but it is fragementary and damaged. It was found in the durrounds of Tilurium however, and is of a similar style to other stelae of Legio VII members. Tončinić 2011: 37-38

column3: Lucius Fabius Saturninus, son of Lucius
Quintus Igneinus Ferox, son of Quintus
column13: Quintus may be a Legio VII member, it is not explicit in his stela however. This possibility is reinforced by the fact that Legio VII member Gaius Curitatus is from Augusta Troas MonumentID 32, CIL 3, 2109
Mitchell 1976: n.50 suggests the city name is similar to several others found in Galatia

column3: Gaius Julius Agrippa, son of Gaius
column13: Other members of Sergia tribe are predominantly from Asia Minor, Tončinić 2011.
Tončinić 2011: 205 purports that this 'city' is likely a ethnic name (nomen ethnicom), and the locaiton is unknown.
No mention of Legio VII as the stelae is damaged. However, style is the same as many other stelae belonging to servicemen of the legio, and it was found at Tilurium.
Tončinić 2011, 50: Could also be Heraclea Macedonia (Betz 1938 and Wilkes 1969), but Fadić 1997 notes that all other extant members of Macedonian decent are of the Voltinia or Aemilia tribe.

column3: Gaius Curiatus Secundus, son of Titus
Publius Lastus Scaeva, son of Aulus
Gaius Lollius Valens, son of Gaius
column13: Asia Minor? Other Papiria member, Lucius Herrenius MonumentID 21 is from Mylias; or Itlay? Sextus Atilius MonumentID 11 is from Ticinum
Brother of MonumentID 45? Found in same plot accoring to Betz 1938: 66; and both epitaphs record the same sized grave plot (20x10ft), Tončinić 2011: 62-63.

Brother of MonumentID 44? (and therefore this is ServicemanID 118) Found in same plot accoring to Betz 1938: 66; and both epitaphs record the same sized grave plot (20x10ft), Tončinić 2011: 62-63. If so, this Gaius could be the 'brother' recorded as the erector of monument MonumentID 44.

Inscription is damaged at the end, so it is difficult to see the capacity in which Gaius references on this tombstone, pressumably as either the 'commemorated' or 'both' (erecting during his lifetime to himself and a certain other Gaius).
Possible serviceman, mentioned on same inscription as ServicemanID 42, but inscription is damaged at the end, could also be a son, freedman and/or heir.

column3: Quintus Marcius Bassus, son of Quintus

column13: Listed here as possible veteran because all other monuments from the surround of pagus Scunasticus relate to veterani.

column3: Quintus Mettius Valens, son of Quintus

column13: Unsure if Augusta Praetoria (Italia) or Augusta Troas (Asia Minor). Tončinić 2011: 204-205; Fadić 1995 168: Troas may be more likely, as Sergia is a common tribe for Asia Minor citizens, and another Member (Gaius Curiatius) does list Augusta Troas as his place of origin (MonumentID 32, CIL 3, 2019).

column3: Gaius Octavius Vitalis, son of Gaius
Lucius Oppius Segninus, son of Lucius

column13: Tončinić 2011: 79-80, Hofmann 1905: 50-51 suggested the reonstruction of 'philippi' for the Domus, as other members of Voltinia tribe are from the site. This has been mostly accepted.
Same individual mentioned is mentioned again in MonumentID 102, where it is revealed he was a centurion.
Relatively safe to assume, as Tončinić does (2011: 82) that Atilius is of the same Domicile as his uncle (ServicemanID 57), for he is of the same tribe.

column3: Lucius Septimius Gratianus, son of Genialis

column13: Tončinić 2011: 84 translates 'sebasto' as Sebatopolis, expecting '-polis' in the next line. Perhaps it could also be Sebaste, for ServicemanID 59 is from this site and is of the same tribe, and therefore 'Sebasto' could here be a carver's 'typo' shall we say, and meant to be 'Sebaste'.

column3: Gaius Valerius Dento, son of Gaius
Marcus Varenus Valens, son of Marcus
Gaius Vatinius Capito, son of Sextus
Gaius Vibius Pudes, son of Gaius

column13: Brother of ServicemanID 82
Brother of ServicemanID 81

column3: Publius Mestrius Maecianus, son of Publius
Gaius Aulius Secundus, son of Gaius

column13: Potentionally a metaphorical 'frater', i.e. fellow serviceman. Not proveable however.
First line of inscription in CIL seems to read [---]O L[-], this last  could be reconstrcuted as [---]O L(ucii)[F(ilius)] and thus 'son of Lucius'
Čače 2003: 16-21, claims this is the same person as ServicemanID 104(monumentID109), spelling his name wrong: S(extus) instead of G/C(aius).
May not refer to a Legio VII member
Čače 2003: 16-21, claims this is the same person as ServicemanID 99, with MonumentID 104 having spelt his name wrong: S(extus) instead of G/C(aius).
Brother of commemorated (ServicemanID 3), but may also be a soldier of Legio VII
Unnamed frater of ServicemanID 10, therefore may be 'comrade' type of frater found in military contexts, see Kepartov 1986
Unlikely that Marcus is blood brother (kin) with the deceased (ServicemanID 28) based on gentilicum, so may be soldier/'comrade' type of frater recorded by Kepartov 1986
Heres of ServicemanID 30, unspecified status, but may be miles.
heredes of ServicemanID 33, unkonwn number and unknown status, may be fellow miles however, as the commemorated was an active miles, and therefore may not have had a family/children/wife etc.
Heres of ServicemanID 12, could therefore be miles as 12 died whilst still on active service
Could be a son, brother, or non-relative of ServicemanID 25 (on account of shared praenomen but not gentilicum) who was also fellow miles
Could be miles of some relation to ServicemanID 35, but 35 was a veteran so may also have been a family member or civilian
Unnamed frater of ServicemanID 38, therefore may be 'comrade' type of frater found in military contexts, see Kepartov 1986

Very likely this is in fact referring to ServicemanID 40. Monument was found in the same plot as MonumentID 44 accoring to Betz 1938: 66; and both epitaphs record the same sized grave plot (20x10ft), Tončinić 2011: 62-63.
Unknown relation to ServicemanID 44, possibly fellow miles
Unnamed heres of ServicemanID 51, could be miles. Indeed, 51 was an active miles when they were commemorated

Commemorator of ServicemanID 62, same tribe as ID 62, but different names (both praenomen and gentilicum), so could be a relative (brother?) from same Eastern city (Isinda), or another site in Asia Minor, for a lot of the members from Asia minor are from the Sergia tribe. Nonetheless, he may be a fellow miles of Legio VII

Commemorator of ServicemanID 65. Likley relative, e.g. son or brother, based on same gentilicum, may have been a miles, however he may also have been a civilian son, for the monument was erected in Salona, and also references a freedwoman named Valeria Quinta, who may have been the wife of ServicemanID 65

Comemmorator of ServicemanID 66 along with ServicemanID 123, could be comrade, son or brother, and possibly a miles as the monument is from Pagus Scunstaicus where there was a large veteran community. However, he may also be a civilian

Comemmorator of ServicemanID 66 along with ServicemanID 122, could be son or brother, and possibly a miles as the monument is from Pagus Scunstaicus where there was a large veteran community. However, he may also be a civilian
Unnamed heres of ServicemanID 69, could be a miles as Pagus Scunasticus was home to a large veteran community, but may also be a civilian son as ID 69 was a settled veteran who may have had a family
Fragmentarily named heres of ServicemanID 73. Monument was found at Tilurium and ServicemanID 73 did die during active duty, so possibly a fellow miles

Son of ServicemanID 17. As his father is possibly a Legio VII miles, Gaius Fabius is possibly one too (perhaps less likely however). His father is of the Sergia tribe, so he may have been a member of it too

Likely the commemorator of ServicemanID 45. Unknown relation, however may have the same gentilicum, and therefore may be the father of ServicemanID 45, as he also has the same praenomen as father of ServicemanID 45. Irrespective of this, he may also have been a fellow miles/veteran

column3: Gaius Julius Theodorus, son of Barceneus

column13: Commemorator of ServicemanID 133, referred to as 'sodalis' (friend), may therefore be fellow soldier. Soldierhood may be even more likely on account of the fact the stelae was likely originally erected at Tilurium. Cambi 1979; 1994.

Commemorator of ServicemanID 132. Referred to as 'frater', perhaps a fellow soldier (comrade) because of different Nomen Gentilicium, but perhaps also fellow solider (kin brother), or just civilian (kin brother). Soldierhood may be more likely on account of the fact the stelae was likely originally erected at Tilurium. Cambi 1979; 1994.

Commemorator of ServicemanID 131. Different nomen gentilicium may mean this individual is unrelated, and they may be a fellow soldier, particularly as 131 died during active service, and the stelae was likely originally erected at Tilurium. Cambi 1979; 1994.
